Change has been successfully merged
Should probably use model instead of CCIN in most places.
Done

In looking at the new code and the existing code for the --get-version option, I think it would make more sense to remove useJsonFile from main().  It is an implementation detail that should be determined at a lower level when the data is actually obtained from JSON or D-Bus.  Forcing higher level callers to pass the variable and know which overloaded function to call seems wrong.

I am planning to soon push a commit that refactors some functionality into a utils.hpp/cpp that is shared across --get-version, --get-model (new), and --update.  I can make the suggested change for useJsonFile in that commit if you prefer.
Renoved useJsonFile to function needs it. We should do same for version above
Why was this needed?
updater::internal::getDevicePath() calls version::utils::getPsuI2c
Shouldn't this blank line be there as a separator?
Done
Why was this needed?
updater::internal::getDevicePath calls version::utils::getPsuI2c
naming convention is that local variables should start with a lower case level (devicePath).
Done
model?
Done

Is this journal message intended to be kept long term?  If so, it probably should be more generic and not mention function names.  Maybe "Found PSU firmware file: {}"?  Also, can't you just specify the filename variable here?
Debug message removed
filename?
Modified return to directory +"/" +filename
What happens if this fails?  I think depending on how the stream is configured it either sets some internal error bits you can check or throws an exception.  Need to handle a failed read.
Done

It is unusual to increment the parameter vs. just setting the parameter to gcount().  At a minimum the doxygen should explain this.  However, I think it would be simpler if it just returned the bytesRead (as the name implies).  Leave it up to the caller to add that to some other variable that is tracking total bytes read.
Done
Should this line be deleted?
Done
Intentional change?
Oops typo
Why did you add this?  This is the old way of avoiding multiple inclusions of the same header.  #pragma once is now the standard way.
Done
Why is this needed?
getDevicePath calls version::utils::getPsuI2c

Why did you move this from private to protected?  Normally we don't want to give class users direct access to internal data members.  If you need to access it in child classes, maybe you want to create a protected method to access it like the new ones below?
accident meant to add protected accessor

It is more efficient to return a const std::string& vs. std::string.

Right now you are forcing a copy to be made.  With a const reference, the caller can assign it to a reference variable and no copy needs to be made.  Same comment on several other new functions below.

Declaring the return type to const can limit usability. I think if we should have "std::string getPsuInventoryPath() const"

Will change to "const std::string getPsuInventoryPath()"
Need to add doxygen comment describing it.
Removed deviceAddress, debug leftover

I think the first 4 methods could be useful for other actions like --get-version and --get-model.  So it would be helpful if these were put in a separate file like utils.hpp/cpp.

I was going to do some similar work in a new commit soon, so if you prefer I can handle it there.
You can add these functions with your commit
This sentence doesn't make sense.  Maybe "Get the device path that corresponds to a PSU inventory path"?
Corrected: Get the device path from the PSU inventory path.
I'm not sure what busId means.  I assume this is just the bus number (like 3)?

BusId listed in the constructor of I2CDevice (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-power/blob/master/tools/i2c/i2c.hpp) I believe it's the bus identifier.

I will change all reference of bus ID to bus
You are right that is my mistake.  I didn't realize the I2C interface class used that term for the bus number.
I2C bus number and device address?
Done
It would probably be better to use the term model, as that is more generic.  CCIN may be an IBM-specific term.
Done
I'd recommend renaming this to model.  If you keep ccin, this is a typo.
Done

I don't think this function or openFirmwareFile should accept a std::optional argument.  Why call them if you don't even have a file name?  If the caller has a std::optional<std::string>, the caller should verify it has a value and then deference it when calling these two functions.
Done
Missing doxygen on this function and the one below.
Done
Resolved all the issues, please review
Just a general comment, is any of this specific to a certain vendor (like the CRC stuff)?  Will the vendor-specific things be named differently, and stored in different files?
Lots of good changes.  I think a few more are needed, but this is close.
is this specific to AEI, if so, should it be prefaced as such?
No this is not specific for AEI

Did you try testing this with an invalid psuInventoryPath?  I'm just asking because the nlohmann::json documentation is confusing about how it handles the case where the key doesn't exist.  It seems like it might automatically add a nullptr value, or it might throw an exception.
No, I did not since this was an old code, I tested new code I added. I have added try and catch around this code.
Nit: spelling error: extension
Done
I don't think you want the ! here right?  It should be "if (fileName.empty())" ?
Done

As we discussed offline, "const std::string" doesn't make sense, since the return type is a copy anyway.

The desired return type is "const std::string&".  Then we don't always make a copy, and the caller can choose to make a copy if they want to modify the value.

You can also add 'const' to the end of this declaration since the method is safe to call if the caller has a const Updater& (e.g. read-only access).

So the final declaration should look like:

```
const std::string& getPsuInventoryPath() const
```

The same comments apply to getDevPath(), getDevName(), and getImageDir().
Done

Please remove the const at the end of this method declaration.  Since it is returning a non-const (writable) pointer to this class's i2c data member, it is allowing the internal state of this class to be modified.  So it is not a const method.
Done
It looks like this isn't overloaded any more?
Done
typo: firmware
Done
This should be "out" right?
Removed numberOfBytesRead

Will the vector.size() always be equal to the number of bytes read?  If so, we probably don't need the numberOfBytesRead output parameter right?

If they can be different, maybe they shouldn't be?  The vector resize() method can be used to modify the size.
Removed numberOfBytesRead
If you decide to keep both numberOfBytesToRead() and numberOfBytesRead(), they should probably have the same data type.  Maybe change numberOfBytesToRead to be a size_t too?
Removed numberOfBytesRead
Thanks for your reviews, Updated the comment please review again

It is possible that read() read fewer than numberOfBytesToRead bytes right?

> Characters are extracted and stored until any of the following conditions occurs:
> * count characters were extracted and stored. 
> * end of file condition occurs on the input sequence (in which case, setstate(failbit|eofbit) is called). The number of successfully extracted characters can be queried using gcount(). 

So this should still determine the number of bytes actually read using gcount().  Then it should set the vector size to that using vector.resize() right?

For example, we try to read 32 bytes, only get 2 (maybe end of file).  So the returned vector should be resized to 2 since only the first two bytes are from the file.

That enables the caller to trust that whatever the vector size is, that is the number of bytes that were read successfully.
Yes, it's possible to read fewer bytes. I will readjust the vector size when reading a fewer bytes.
